marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Andrew Clow (1750-1793) was a Philadelphia coastal shipping merchant.

Business papers chiefly from merchants in Charleston, S.C.; Alexandria, Va.; and Hagerstown, Md.; concerning the shipment of goods, efforts to collect money, and trade conditions. Also included are bills of Andrew Clow & Co., and a letter describing activity of the British fleet around Philadelphia.

Revolutionary War soldier and aide-de-camp to General George Washington, speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives and president of the Senate, physician, judge, member of Congress, lieutenant governor of Massachusetts, and a founder of the Society of the Cincinnati and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. At the time of this letter, Cobb was a resident of Gouldsboro, Maine.
Collection comprises a letter to Charles W. Hare, in Philadelphia, regarding Cobb's land development activities in Maine.
Richard Ivanhoe Cocke (1820-1873) was a planter, of Fluvanna County, Va.
Promissory notes, accounts, and other business papers of planter Richard Cocke.
John Hartwell Cocke (1780-1866) was a planter, agricultural reformer, and brigadier general in the War of 1812.

Collection contains Cocke's letters concerning the purchase of land in Perry Co., Ala., the weather, crop conditions, prices, and the health of slaves. Other items include letters to Dr. Cary Charles Cocke, son of J.H. Cocke; a report on the progress of a younger John Hartwell Cocke at the University of Virginia; and the will and accompanying documents of Philip St. George Cocke, son of J.H. Cocke.
Howell Cobb (1815-1868) was a lawyer, member of the U.S. Congress, member of President Buchanan's cabinet, Confederate major general, and governor of Georgia; from Athens (Clarke Co.), Ga.

Papers concern the Georgia tax system; Whig and Democratic politics in Georgia; Cobb's work in Congress and as Secretary of the Treasury; disaffection with the Confederate government in Georgia; and military activities, including a letter, 1863, from Robert Toombs about raising a regiment for home defense, and a letter, April 1865, to Joseph E. Brown about sending troops to aid Alabama. Also included are a letter, 1860, from wife Mary Ann Lamar Cobb, describing a state dinner and a party at the White House for the Prince of Wales; and a memorial prepared by the Macon bar at Cobb's death.
A. Jackson Cochran was a Greenbrier Co., W. Va. resident.
Collection contains papers of Cochran and members of the Cochran family. They include sheriff's summonses and personal letters.

Pertains to sheep and wool production in the United States. Cockrill wrote that he had produced wool as fine as any in Europe and stressed the importance of pedigreed livestock. He also invited Patterson to travel to his home so that he could convince Patterson that the warm climate in Nashville would produce fine wool over the entire sheep body. Cockrill ordered two additional rams.
Mark Cockrill was a wool producer.
Thomas Read Rootes Cobb (1823-1862) was a Georgia statesman and Confederate general, from Cherry Hill (Jefferson Co.), Ga.

Civil War papers and routine political correspondence, including pay vouchers for enlisted men and officers in Cobb's Georgia Legion, two letters regarding the death of Edward F. Bagley, 1861, and a letter to his wife from Fredericksburg, Va., discussing the war.
Albert A. Cobb and Company papers,
Routine business letters pertaining to Albert A. Cobb and Company and other insurance companies.
Autograph album containing verses from friends to Mary Willing Clymer.
Mary Willing Clymer was a resident of Washington, D.C.
Letter from Howell Cobb to Col. H.H. Waters concerning the role of Governor Joseph E. Brown in the forthcoming international and industrial exhibition at Macon, Ga.
Howell Cobb (1795-1864) was a lawyer, author, planter and politician born in Savannah, Ga. who moved to Houston County, Ga.
Job Cobb was a Confederate soldier, from Tarboro (Edgecombe Co.), N.C.

Letters from Cobb, a private in the Confederate Army, stationed first at Yorktown and later at Richmond, Va., during the Peninsular Campaign, 1862. The letters mention rations, food prices, and his hatred of the enemy.
John Lewis Cochran was an editor, lawyer, Confederate Army captain, and judge of Charlottesville (Albemarle Co.), Va.

Collection contains Cochran's business letters; a business receipt signed by James Cocke Southall (1827-1897); and a stock certificate signed by William T. Early (1817-1874), president, Albemarle Insurance Co.
William A. Cockefair was a Union soldier, member of the 15th Regiment, Indiana Volunteers.
Diary discusses military activities of Cockefair's regiment in Virginia, Kentucky, Tennessee, Mississippi, and Alabama.
Francis Marion Cockrell (1834-1915) was a U.S. Senator from Missouri.
Collection consists of Cockrell's routine correspondence while serving in the Senate. Some biographical material is also included.

Diary kept by S. Coates of Narragansett Pier, Rhode Island, the apparently affluent wife of Harry Coates. They traveled to Georgia; Florida; Yonkers, New York; as well as Philadelphia and Point Pleasant, Pennsylvania. The volume also contains descriptions of her active social life in Rhode Island; at the end are a few cash accounts and a list of names and addresses.
